{{Infobox event | Event_Name = Taxpayer March on Washington | Image_Name = Taxpayer March on Washington.jpg | Imagesize = 250px | Image_Caption = Protesters walking towards the [[United States Capitol]] during the march | Location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | Date = September 12, 2009 | URL = [http://912dc.org/ 912DC.org] }} The '''Taxpayer March on Washington''' (also known as the '''9/12 Tea Party''') was a [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] protest march from [[Freedom Plaza]] to the [[United States Capitol]] held on September 12, 2009, in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name=wsjournal>{{Cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125276685577405975?mod=rss_Today%27s_Most_Popular | title=Protesters March on Washington | last=Sherman | first=Jake | date=September 13, 2009 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | publisher=online.wsj.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=atlanta>{{Cite news| url=http://www.ajc.com/news/georgians-lead-protest-at-137117.html?imw=Y | title=Georgians lead protest at Taxpayer March on Washington | last=Keefe | first=Bob | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] | publisher=ajc.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref> The event coincided with [[Tea Party protests|similar protests]] organized in various cities across the nation.<ref name=politico>{{Cite news| url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0909/27077.html | title=Protests present GOP with tricky task | last=Vogel | first=Kenneth P. |author2=Isenstadt, Alex | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[The Politico]] | publisher=politico.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref> The protesters rallied against what they consider [[big government]], the dismantling of [[free market]] [[capitalism]], [[Abortion in the United States|abortion]], and [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]]'s proposals on [[Health care reform in the United States|health care reform]], [[Taxation in the United States|taxation]], and [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] [[United States federal budget|spending]], among other issues.<ref name=politico/><ref name=nytimes>{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/13/us/politics/13protestweb.html?hp | title=Thousands Rally in Capital to Protest Big Government | last=Zeleny | first=Jeff | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher=nytimes.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=telegraph>{{Cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/6180381/Anti-Barack-Obama-health-care-protesters-pour-into-Washington.html | title=Anti-Barack Obama health care protesters pour into Washington | last=Doyle | first=Leonard | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | publisher=telegraph.co.uk | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=bbcnews>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8252939.stm | title=Protests over Obama health reform | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[BBC News]] | publisher=[[BBC News Online|news.bbc.co.uk]] | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=newyorktimes>{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/14/business/14big.html?bl&ex=1253073600&en=7d2e3c685d12733a&ei=5087 | title=U.S. Is Finding Its Role in Business Hard to Unwind | last=Andrews | first=Edmund L. | authorlink=Edmund Andrews (reporter)|author2=Sanger, David E. |authorlink2=David E. Sanger | date=September 13, 2009 | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher=nytimes.com | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=gabywood>{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/29/glenn-beck-obama-fox-opposition | title=Glenn Beck: the renegade running the opposition to Obama | last=Wood | first=Gaby | date=November 29, 2009 | work=[[The Observer]] | publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]] | page=4 | accessdate=November 30, 2009 }}</ref>
The lead organizer of the event was [[Brendan Steinhauser]], who was serving as the Director of Federal and State Campaigns for FreedomWorks. Organizers of the event included the [[9-12 Project]], [[FreedomWorks]], the [[National Taxpayers Union]], [[The Heartland Institute]], [[Americans for Tax Reform]], Tea Party Patriots, ResistNet and [[Americans for Prosperity]].<ref name=wapo>{{Cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/12/AR2009091200971.html | title=Lashing Out at the Capitol: Tens of Thousands Protest Obama Initiatives and Government Spending | last=Brown | first=Emma |author2=Hohmann, James |author3=Bacon, Perry | date=September 13, 2009 | work=[[The Washington Post]] | publisher=washingtonpost.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=irish>{{Cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/world-news/us-healthcare-protesters-rally-against-obama-plan-1885651.html | title=US healthcare protesters rally against Obama plan | last=Wolf | first=Carol | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[Irish Independent]] | publisher=independent.ie | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=theguardian>{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/13/barack-obama-denounced-washington-march | title=Barack Obama denounced by rightwing marchers in Washington | last=Pilkington | first=Ed | date=September 13, 2009 | work=[[The Guardian]] | publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]] | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=alex>{{Cite news| url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0909/27070.html | work=[[The Politico]] | publisher=politico.com | date=September 12, 2009 | title='Freedom fighters' take a stand in D.C. | first=Alex | last=Isenstadt | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=guardian20090918/> The event was also promoted by [[Fox News]] commentator [[Glenn Beck]] as a symbol of what he called "national unity" following the eight-year anniversary of the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref name=theage>{{Cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/demonstrators-attack-obamas-socialist-reforms-20090913-fm5q.html | title=Demonstrators attack Obama's 'socialist' reforms | last=Wolf | first=Carol | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[Bloomberg Television|Bloomberg News]] | publisher=[[The Age|theage.com.au]] | accessdate=September 18, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=harness>{{Cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125469984687962987?mod=WSJ_hpp_MIDDLENexttoWhatsNewsSecond | title=FreedomWorks Harnesses Growing Activism on the Right | last=Phillips | first=Michael M. | date=October 5, 2009 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | publisher=online.wsj.com | page=A4 | accessdate=October 5, 2009 }}</ref> The march is the largest gathering of [[Fiscal conservatism|fiscal]] [[Conservatism in the United States|conservatives]] ever held in Washington, D.C.,<ref name=washind>{{Cite news|url=http://washingtonindependent.com/59109/beltway-conservatives-comb-tea-party-movement-for-converts |title=Beltway Conservatives Comb Tea Party Movement for Converts |last=Weigel |first=David |date=September 14, 2009 |work=[[Center for Independent Media|The Washington Independent]] |publisher=washingtonindependent.com |accessdate=September 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922172005/http://washingtonindependent.com/59109/beltway-conservatives-comb-tea-party-movement-for-converts |archivedate=September 22, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name=economist>{{Cite news| url=http://www.economist.com/world/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14470048 | title=Politics this week | date=September 17, 2009 | work=[[The Economist]] | publisher=economist.com | accessdate=September 18, 2009 }}</ref> as well as the largest demonstration against [[Presidency of Barack Obama|President Obama's administration]].<ref name=nytimes/>
A wide range of [[Crowd counting|crowd estimates]] was suggested for the event,<ref name=crowds/> with most media sourcing the [[Public Information Officer]] of the [[District of Columbia Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department|D.C. Fire Department]], who unofficially estimated the attendance "in excess of 75,000" people.<!-- before changing the estimate, please discuss it on the talk page first. Thanks. --><ref name=wsjournal/><ref name=crowds/><ref name=goldman/><ref name=attendance>{{Cite news| url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/protest-crowd-size-estimate-falsely-attributed-abc-news/story?id=8558055 | title=ABC News Was Misquoted on Crowd Size | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[ABC News]] | publisher=abcnews.go.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref> The D.C. Fire Department later released a statement saying that they do not do crowd estimates, and any crowd estimation attributed to them was false; they also stated that an early estimate of 60,000 over Twitter was for a specific area, Freedom Plaza, not the total number of participants in the event.<ref name=dcfd/> Event organizers also reported a range of attendance. FreedomWorks suggested between 600,000 and 800,000 participants while National Taxpayers Union said 200,000 to 300,000.<ref name=crowds/>
==Event activity==
===Timeline===
[[File:Sept 12, 2009 - Tea Party Tax Payer Protest, Washington DC.jpg|thumb|Protesters on the West Lawn looking toward the United States Capitol Building]]
[[FreedomWorks]] began planning the event in March 2009, according to a FreedomWorks spokesperson.<ref name=alex/> The [[political advocacy group]]s [[Americans for Prosperity]] and FreedomWorks were "probably the leading partners" in the event, according to ''The Guardian''.<ref name=guardian20090918>{{cite news |first=Ed |last=Pilkington |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/18/republicans-internet-barack-obama |title=Republicans steal Barack Obama's internet campaigning tricks |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=September 18, 2009 |accessdate=April 5, 2015}}</ref>
On Saturday, September 12, participants gathered at Freedom Plaza, located just east of the [[White House]].<ref name=usatoday>{{Cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-09-11-tax-rally_N.htm | title=Tens of thousands rally in D.C. against federal spending | last=Seaman | first=Andrew |author2=Bazar, Emily | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[USA Today]] | publisher=usatoday.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref> The march was scheduled to proceed [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]] at 11:30 a.m., led by a [[Ancient Fife and Drum Corps|fife and drum corps]], and march towards [[Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C.|Capitol Hill]]; however due to a larger-than-expected number of protesters, the Plaza and surrounding area became overcrowded and the march set off one hour ahead of schedule.<ref name=latimes>{{Cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-capitol-rally13-2009sep13,0,5742055.story | title=Massive crowd marches against Obama's agenda | last=Barabak | first=Mark Z. | date=September 13, 2009 | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | publisher=latimes.com | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=yahoo>{{Cite news| url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20090913/pl_afp/usdemogovernmentobama | title=Thousands rally against Obama | last=Zeitvogel | first=Karin | date=September 13, 2009 | work=[[Agence France-Presse]] | publisher=[[Yahoo! News|news.yahoo.com]] | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
[[C-SPAN]] recorded the entire two-hour-50-minute rally, which was officially kicked off at 1:11 p.m. with a welcoming speech by Jenny Beth Martin, the co-founder and national coordinator of [[Tea Party Patriots]].<ref name=cspan>{{Cite web| url=http://www.c-span.org/Watch/Media/2009/09/12/HP/A/23055/FreedomWorks+Rally+in+DC.aspx | title=FreedomWorks Rally in DC | work=[[C-SPAN]] | publisher=(c-span.org) | date=September 12, 2009| accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref>
During the march, most protesters sang [[American patriotic music|patriotic songs]], chanted [[List of political slogans|political slogans]], waved the [[Flag of the United States|American flag]] or yellow [[Gadsden flag]], or held signs covering a wide range of [[Politics of the United States|political topics]].<ref name=politico/><ref name=telegraph/><ref name=goldman/><ref name=gadsden>{{Cite news| url=http://washingtontimes.com/news/2009/sep/14/hot-button-18902351/?feat=home_columns | title=Don't tread on me | last=Carpenter | first=Amanda | authorlink=Amanda Carpenter | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[The Washington Times]] | publisher=washingtontimes.com | accessdate=October 1, 2009 }}</ref>
===Signage=== [[File:Tea Party sign - US Capitol.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Protest sign with the [[United States Capitol dome]] in the background]] Though many of the signs were close to the original Tea Party message of "Taxed Enough Already," such as "Stop Obama's Spending Spree," some of the handwritten signs carried by protesters included statements such as "Liar Liar Pants on Fire!" and "Hey Obamacare! Hands off my body".<ref name=telegraph/><ref name=healy>{{Cite news | url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/columns/March-on-9_12-shows-the-Right-on-the-rise-8243662.html | title=Gene Healy: March on 9/12 shows the Right on the rise | last=Healy | first=Gene | authorlink=Gene Healy | date=September 15, 2009 | work=[[The Washington Examiner]] | publisher=washingtonexaminer.com | accessdate=September 28, 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721001328/http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/columns/March-on-9_12-shows-the-Right-on-the-rise-8243662.html | archivedate=July 21, 2010 | df= }}</ref><ref name=waposign>{{Cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/13/AR2009091302538.html | title=Seeking Healing, Seeing Hostility | last=Alcindor | first=Yamiche | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[The Washington Post]] | publisher=washingtonpost.com | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> Other signs promoted [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|Obama citizenship conspiracy theories]], depicted the [[Barack Obama "Joker" poster|Obama "Joker" image]], and compared Obama to [[Adolf Hitler]].<ref name=politico/><ref name=telegraph/><ref name=goldman>{{Cite news| url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/tea-party-protesters-march-washington/story?id=8557120 | title=Tea Party Protesters March on Washington | last=Goldman | first=Russell | date=September 12, 2009 | work=[[ABC News]] | publisher=abcnews.go.com | accessdate=September 14, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=npr>{{Cite news| url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=112781731&ps=cprs | title=Crowds Pack Downtown D.C. To Protest Spending | last=Keyes | first=Allison | date=September 12, 2009|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[National Public Radio|npr.org]] | accessdate=September 13, 2009 }}</ref> One protester commented that many signs were "expressing concerns about the tax burdens to be carried by "our grandchildren" and other signs he didn't feel were appropriate to repeat".<ref name=sherman/> [[Gene Healy]], author and vice president at the [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] [[Cato Institute]], expressed the opinion that the signs generally focused on opposition to government [[bailout]]s, Obama's proposal on [[America's Affordable Health Choices Act of 2009|health care reform]], and the appointment of [[Czar (political term)|presidential "czars"]].<ref name="healy"/>
===Speakers=== Among the speakers at the rally were former [[Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives|House Majority Leader]] [[Dick Armey]], chairman of FreedomWorks, and a small number of congressional [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] including Representative [[Mike Pence]], chairman of the [[House Republican Conference]], Representative [[Tom Price (American politician)|Tom Price]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], Senator [[Jim DeMint]] of [[South Carolina]], and Representative [[Marsha Blackburn]] of [[Tennessee]]. Pence said that "Americans want health care reform, but they don't want government takeover".<ref name=sherman>{{Cite news|url=http://www.heralddemocrat.com/hd/News/2009_09-15_news_Taxpayer-March-on-Washington |title=Sherman man discusses his part in the taxpayer march on Washington |date=September 14, 2009 |last=Goodwin |first=Joyce |work=[[The Herald Democrat]] |publisher=heralddemocrat.com |accessdate=September 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711163437/http://www.heralddemocrat.com/hd/News/2009_09-15_news_Taxpayer-March-on-Washington |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name=agenda>{{Cite web| url=http://912dc.org/agenda/ | title=Agenda | work=[[FreedomWorks]] | publisher=(912dc.org) | accessdate=September 16, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=armey>{{Cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/26/AR2009092602438.html?wprss=rss_business | title=Armey's Army Marches Against Obama | last=Pershing | first=Ben | date=September 27, 2009 | work=[[The Washington Post]] | publisher=washingtonpost.com | page=A08 | accessdate=October 6, 2009 }}</ref>
==Attendance== [[Image:Tea Party - Pennsylvania Avenue.jpg|thumb|Protesters walking down [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]]]] Following the event, a wide range of [[Crowd counting|crowd estimates]] was reported by organizers, protesters, and [[News media|members of the media]].<ref name=crowds>{{Cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-crowd15-2009sep15,0,1062512.story | title=Crowd estimates vary wildly for Capitol march | last=Markman | first=Joe | date=September 15, 2009 | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | publisher=latimes.com | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> The space occupied by the crowd extended from the [[United States Capitol|Capitol]] lawn down around the [[National Mall]] as far as Third Street.<ref name=salon>{{Cite news| title=The final word on crowd size | date=September 14, 2009 | last=Koppelman | first=Alex | work=[[Salon.com]] | publisher=salon.com | url=http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/feature/2009/09/14/crowd_size/ | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> The crowd estimates mentioned in many news outlets included "tens of thousands"<ref name=economist/> and "between 60,000 and 75,000",<ref name=wsjournal/><ref name=atlanta/><ref name=politifact/> while many sourced the [[Public Information Officer]] of the [[District of Columbia Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department|D.C. Fire Department]] who unofficially estimated there were "in excess of 75,000" people in attendance.<ref name=wsjournal/><ref name=crowds/><ref name=goldman/><ref name="attendance"/> The D.C. Fire Department later released a statement that the crowd estimation attributed to them was false and based on an early estimation of a specific area, Freedom Plaza, not the number of participants in the event.<ref name=dcfd>{{Cite web |url=http://newsroom.dc.gov/show.aspx/agency/fems/section/2/release/18165 | title="DC Fire Department Report" Quote Regarding September 12 Event Misrepresents Agency Policy |agency= [[District of Columbia Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department]] | publisher=(newsroom.dc.gov) | date=September 21, 2009 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131111103059/http://newsroom.dc.gov/show.aspx/agency/fems/section/2/release/18165 |archive-date = 2013-11-11 |accessdate = 2018-04-21 }}</ref>
Conservative [[blog]]gers, stating estimates reported in the news were [[media bias in the United States|liberal media bias]], asserted the number was much higher and estimated between 1 and 2 million people had attended the event.<ref name=crowds/><ref name=politifact/><ref name=achenbach>{{Cite news| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/achenblog/2009/09/the_perils_of_crowd_estimates.html | title=The Perils of Crowd Estimates | last=Achenbach | first=Joel | authorlink=Joel Achenbach | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[The Washington Post]] | publisher=voices.washingtonpost.com | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> [[St. Petersburg Times#Politifact.com|PolitiFact]], ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'', the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', and other news outlets reported that some of these bloggers, such as [[Michelle Malkin]], had originally distributed photos from a 1997 [[Promise Keepers]] march that made the 2009 march look more highly attended.<ref name=politifact>{{Cite web| url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2009/sep/14/tea-party-photo-shows-large-crowd-different-event/ | title="Tea party" photo shows huge crowd – at different event | last=Richert | first=Catharine | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[St. Petersburg Times|Politifact]] | publisher=(politifact.com) | accessdate=September 14, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=csmonitor>{{Cite news| url=http://features.csmonitor.com/politics/2009/09/14/that-photo-of-the-912-march-on-washington-its-fake/ | title=That photo of the 9/12 march on Washington? It’s fake. | last=Shaer | first=Matthew | date=September 14, 2009 | work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] | publisher=csmonitor.com | accessdate=September 14, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=latimesfake>{{Cite news| title=Tea Party Protest Photo is a Fake | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/09/tea-party-protest-photo-is-a-fake.html | date=September 14, 2009 | last=Linthicum | first=Kate | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | publisher=latimesblogs.latimes.com | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> Adding difficulty to crowd estimation, a section of the National Mall near the [[Washington Monument]] was dedicated to the 24th annual [[National Black Family Reunion]] on September 12.<ref name=waposign/> [[Image:TeaPartyByFreedomFan.JPG|thumb|Protesters walking down Pennsylvania Avenue]] [[Matt Kibbe]], president of [[FreedomWorks]], the organizer of the event, stated on stage that [[ABC News]] had reported 1 million to 1.5 million protesters in attendance. ABC News later published an article saying that they were misquoted by Kibbe, and went on to report that 60,000 to 70,000 had attended the event, citing the unofficial D.C. Fire Department number.<ref name=attendance/> After comparing photographs of Saturday's protest with previous events, FreedomWorks revised their crowd estimate to be between 600,000 and 800,000.<ref name=crowds/><ref name=tpm>{{Cite web| url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2009/09/freedomworks-cuts-estimate-for-crowd-at-its-912-rally-by-one-half.php | title=FreedomWorks Cuts Estimate For Crowd At Its 9/12 Rally By One Half | date=September 14, 2009 | last=Kleefeld | first=Eric | work=[[Talking Points Memo]] | publisher=(tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com) | accessdate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref> Pete Sepp, a spokesman for the [[National Taxpayers Union]], one of the organizations that sponsored the march, said the group estimated the crowd at 75,000 in the morning and from 200,000 and 300,000 as the day went on.<ref name=crowds/>
[[Farouk El-Baz]], a [[Boston University]] research professor and expert on crowd estimation, told the ''[[LA Times]]'' that his informal research from media coverage indicated 75,000 as the peak attendance. El-Baz noted that, because there seemed to be no aerial photos of the event, reaching any sort of rigorous estimate might be impossible. The [[Washington Metro]] reported 87,000 extra riders that day as compared to the average ridership.<ref name=crowds/>
==2010 March==
Another march was held on September 12, 2010, in Washington, with, according to [[FOX News]], a "thousands-strong" crowd.<ref name = "Fox News 2010">[http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/09/12/project-gathers-tea-partiers-ahead-midterm/ Tea Partiers Rally, Send Warning to Lawmakers Ahead of Midterm]</ref> Two other major tea parties were held in [[Sacramento, California]], which attracted "thousands" and [[St. Louis, Missouri]].<ref>[https://www.heraldnet.com/news/coast-to-coast-tea-partiers-promote-their-cause/ Coast to coast, tea partiers promote their cause (AP)]</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Energy Security for the Future- New Sources, Responsibility, Sustainability (ESF).png|thumb| Energy Security for the Future: New Sources, Responsibility, Sustainability ]] '''The International Forum on Energy Security for the Future: New Sources, Responsibility, Sustainability(ESF)''' is an initiative on energy security focused on popularization of alternative energy sources in Europe and worldwide.<ref>http://energysecurityforum.org/</ref><ref>http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/press-release/348430.html</ref><ref>http://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-politics/2015108-international-forum-on-energy-security-electric-marathon-begin-in-ukraine-in-june.html</ref> Founded by the [[Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation]],<ref>http://www.fpa2.com/home.html</ref> [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]]'s Foundation "Amicus Europae"<ref>http://fae.pl/</ref> and Ukraine's leading private oil & gas producer [[Burisma Holdings|Burisma]] Group<ref>http://burisma.com/en/news/albert-ii-prince-of-monaco-and-burisma-held-the-first-international-forum-on-energy-security-in-europe/</ref> in 2016. The founders of the Forum are [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|HSH Prince Albert II of Monaco]], [[Mykola Zlochevsky|Nikolay Zlochevskyi]] and [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]]. The Head of the Organizing Committee of the Forum is [http://burisma.com/en/director/vadim-pozharskij/ Vadym Pozharskyi.] [[File:Energy Security Forum2017.jpg|thumb|Energy Security Forum 2017]] The Forum<ref>http://www.kplctv.com/story/31796703/burisma-group-together-with-the-prince-albert-ii-of-monaco-foundation-will-be-holding-a-european-forum-on-energy-security-for-the-future-new-sources</ref> offers an exclusive discussion platform to address energy security matters and supports an equal and open dialogue between states, governments, business people, expert community and civil society about the transition to a green economy and renewable energy sources.<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/burisma-group-together-with-the-prince-albert-ii-of-monaco-foundation-will-be-holding-a-european-forum-on-energy-security-for-the-future-new-sources-responsibility-sustainability-300256320.html</ref>
== History and background == First held on June 2, 2016, in Monte Carlo, Monaco, the '''Forum on Energy Security for the Future: New sources, Responsibility, Sustainability'''<ref>http://www.thinkgeoenergy.com/energy-security-for-the-future-international-forum-monaco-june-2-2016/</ref> promotes non-polluting renewable energy. It calls for close cooperation and coordination among countries, organizations and civil society to address common security challenges and energy concerns.
With more than 150 guests in attendance, including European politicians, energy experts, journalists and owners of Europe's largest energy companies, the Forum has already gained recognition as the most ambitious European project on energy security issues and promotion of alternative energy sources.
"This is such a unique occasion, when a Forum managed to bring together different people of different social status to address European energy security. Organized by the Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation and Burisma Group, the Forum doesn't only attempt to attract socially responsible businesses and civil society over the idea of energy security, it also offers an exclusive discussion platform that allows participants to share their thoughts and lay foundation for a comprehensive long-term strategy of energy security in Europe", admitted co-founder of the Forum and the President of Burisma Group Nikolay Zlochevskyi.
The Forum was opened by HSH Prince Albert II of Monaco. In his speech he focused on the need to develop alternative energy sources and outlined that the topic of the Forum was “essential” for a secure and prosperous future of European states. [[File:Energy Security Forum 2017.jpg|thumb|Energy Security Forum 2017]] “Energy security planning has to be done in a long-term perspective,” the Prince noted. “We should pay more attention to renewable energy sources that would enable getting cheap energy without polluting the environment.”
Organized by Burisma Group in partnership with the Adam Smith Conferences, and with support from the Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation and the [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]]'s Foundation Amicus Europae, the '''Second International Forum on Energy Security for the Future: New vision, Strategy, Innovation''' took place on June 2, 2017 in Monte Carlo, Monaco. The event addressed Europe’s energy security with focus on Ukraine’s increasing role in the European energy market.
“This event goes in line with our corporate objectives, but most importantly, it reflects values and principles that we, at Burisma Group, stand by: integrity, social responsibility and innovation. We are proud that the Forum is becoming Europe’s largest energy platform. Every year, more and more politicians and public figures join in to aid the cause. With the support from the Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation, we are hoping that our Forum will bring tangible results for the entire Europe”, admitted the Head of the Organizing Committee and Advisor to the Board of Directors at Burisma Group [[:uk:Пожарський_Вадим_Юрійович|Vadym Pozharskyi]]..
'''The third annual Forum on''' '''ENERGY SECURITY FOR THE FUTURE''' will take place on June 1, 2018 in Monte Carlo, Monaco. The Forum will address revolutionary thinking necessary to strengthen energy security and latest innovative accomplishments in the energy sector.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://energysecurityforum.org/2018|title=2018|website=energysecurityforum.org|language=ru-ru|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref>
== Forum participants and topics ==
=== Forum 2016 === The Forum speakers induced such high-European politicians as [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]] (President of Poland 1995-2005), [[Joschka Fischer]] (Vice-Chancellor of Germany 1998-2005), [[Andris Piebalgs]] (EU Commissioner for Energy, 2004 and 2009), TJ Glautier (US Vice-Secretary of Energy 1999-2001, President of TJG Energy Associates), [[Hunter Biden]] (Independent director of Burisma), Ireneusz Bil (Director of Amicus Europae, the Foundation of Aleksander Kwaśniewski), Jean-Arnold Vinois (European Commission representative on Energy Policy issues) and other honored guests.
'''The attendees discussed the following topics:''' * Alter-Eco: New energy for the "New" Europe * Energy Sources: Geopolitics and Diversification * A Necessary Balance: Environmental security and corporate responsibility[[File:Energy Security for the Future 2016.jpg|thumb|Energy Security for the Future 2016]] The Next Steps: An Alternative Energy Road Map and Public-private partnerships
The first Energy Security Forum also became a platform for presentation of the English version of Mission Ukraine written by the Polish author Maciej Olchawa. The book reflects the vision of the European Community and Ukraine’s place in it and reveals new interesting details of the Cox-Kwasniewski Mission, which played the key role during the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|Revolution of Dignity]] in Ukraine.
In his book Maciej Olchawa talks about European integration, Ukraine’s place in Europe and the world, modern leaders and new political elites formation. The book also suggests a new strategy of the EU international politics from the perspective of Ukrainian events. Aleksander Kwaśniewski presented the book Mission Ukraine, together with the author they held an autograph session and promised to publish a Ukrainian version of the book.
=== Forum 2017 === For the second year in a row, the Forum on Energy Security for the Future: new vision, strategy, innovation brought together over 250 guests including global leaders, politicians, energy experts and journalists. The Forum started with welcoming remarks from His Serene Highness Prince Albert II of Monaco, followed by keynote addresses from the President of Slovenia (2007–2012) Danilo Türk and the Prime Minister of Belgium (1999–2008) and the Leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group Guy Verhofstadt<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://burisma.com/en/news/global-leaders-to-convene-at-second-energy-security-forum-in-monaco-2/|title=Global Leaders Convene at Second Energy Security Forum in Monaco {{!}} Burisma|website=burisma.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref>.
The panelists of the keynote session included the Vice Prime Minister of Ukraine Volodymyr Kistion, the Director of the CIA’s Counterterrorist Center (1999-2002) and Ambassador at Large for Counter-Terrorism (2002-2004) [[Cofer Black|Joseph Cofer Black]], the European Commissioner for Energy (2004 and 2009) Andris Piebalgs, and the Director of the Atlantic Council Dina Patriciu Eurasia Center and the US Ambassador to Ukraine (2003-2006) John E. Herbst. They focused on the role of institutions in strengthening European energy security.<ref>https://www.kyivpost.com/business-wire/global-leaders-convene-second-energy-security-forum-monaco.html</ref>
The first session closed with a keynote presentation from the President of Poland (1995-2005) Alexander Kwasniewski. The analytical market debate, moderated by the EU Platts correspondent Siobhan Hall, placed special emphasis on latest trends affecting the European energy market, including energy landscape changes, supply and demand dynamics and competition. The Forum addressed European energy security at a regional level and development of energy-efficient infrastructure<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/global-leaders-convene-at-second-energy-security-forum-in-monaco-626964521.html</ref>.
In attendance from the Ukrainian side were the Vice Prime Minister of Ukraine Volodymyr Kistion, the Head of the Committee on Taxation and Customs Policy at the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine Nina Yuzhanina, Deputy Minister for International Integration at the Ministry of Energy and Coal Industry of Ukraine Nataliya Boyko, as well as representatives of the Embassy of Ukraine in France, the Cabinet of Ministers, Ministries and Departments.
“The processes taking place in the EU automatically affect Ukraine and vice versa. Such events allow Ukrainian and European leaders share their views and define instruments required to obtain energy independence at a country level and in the whole Europe”, noted the President of Burisma Group [http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/press-release/426573.html Nikolay Zlochevsky].
=== Forum 2018 === On June 1, 2018, in Monte Carlo (Principality of Monaco); organized by the largest gas-extracting company of Ukraine Burisma Group, the 3rd International Forum on Energy Security in Europe - Energy Security for the Future was held with the partnership of the Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation<ins> </ins>Alexander Kwasniewski Foundation - Amicus Europae and Atlantic Council also became partners of the Forum. The third forum from the European event turned into a global event in the field of energy and environmental security. This year the Forum was attended by about 250 people, representing more than 20 countries<ins>.</ins>
The event was informally called the "Forum of Presidents", which brought together political leaders of European countries, among which are His Serene Highness Prince Albert II of Monaco; President of Latvia Raymonds Vejonis, former President of Poland (1995-2005) Alexander Kwasniewski; President of the European Commission and Prime Minister of Italy Romano Prodi; President of the European Council and Prime Minister of the Czech Republic Mirek Topolanek and His Excellency Bernard Fortier, Vice-President of Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation. Discussions of the Forum were attended by Mark Pritchard, the member of the UK Parliament and leader of the delegation to OSCE; U.S. politician and senior senator from the state of Louisiana, Mary Loretta Landrieu; the Latvian politician and the diplomat, the commissioner of the European Union on power and development Andris Piebalgs; Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary and Director of the Dinu Patriciu Eurasia Center of the Atlantic Council, John Edward Herbst and others<ins>.</ins>
The vector of revolutionary thinking, changes and the introduction of new technologies became the topic of the Forum 2018 Economic relations, energy, and politics are undergoing one of the most ambitious changes in history<ins>. </ins>The economic activity of the world leaders changes the generally accepted views on doing business, ideology, and model of life activity<ins>.</ins>
Energy Security for the Future 2018, Monaco
According to the founder of the Forum on Energy Security for the Future and the President of Burisma Group - Nikolai Zlochevskyi, For the last three years, the Energy Security for the Future forum has acquired the status of the largest public, political, economic and innovation movement aimed at bringing together all politicians and people around the formation of a single, secure European alliance. “Only consolidation can effectively promote the new innovative formats of clean energy sources in the lives of Europeans. Taking into account interdependence and global challenges, only a strong, energetically independent Europe can guarantee a future for its peoples. Ukraine is already an important strategic link in the overall system of energy security in Europe", - Nikolai Zlochevskyi said.
== Partners ==
Since its creation in 2016, the Forum on Energy Security for the Future has established partnerships with a diverse range of stakeholders and international organizations interested in accelerating renewable energy deployment and introduction of latest technologies. These alliances reflect a commitment to long-term promotion of renewable energy around the world.
To advance its mission, the Forum<ref>http://nvs24.com/news/energy/Burisma-Group-Together-With-the-Prince-Albert-II-of-Monaco-Foundation-Will-Be-Holding-a-European-Forum-on-Energy-Security-for-the-Future-New-Sources-Responsibility-Sustainability-5219401.html</ref> is closely working with the Aleksander Kwaśniewski's foundation "Amicus Europae"<ref>http://kwasniewskialeksander.pl/english/presidents-activities/foundation-amicus-europae</ref> on the development of the European Neighborhood Policy, with a special focus on Ukraine and Belarus and fostering the transatlantic dialogue and future of Europe debates.
"The topic of this forum is very important, as energy is a key factor not just today -- it will also remain a key factor in the future," Kwaśniewski said. "The modern world is changing faster than ever. I hope that Burisma will continue to support such initiatives".<ref>http://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/business-wire/albert-ii-prince-of-monaco-and-burisma-held-the-first-international-forum-on-energy-security-in-europe-415691.html</ref>
In 2017, the British professional team [http://www.adamsmithconferences.com/ Adam Smith Conferences] became official partners of the Forum, transforming event into a truly global conference. As the 2016 Forum, the 2017 Forum was supported by The Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation, [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]]'s Foundation Amicus Europae and [http://energysecurityforum.org/partners other high-profile organizations.]
The Forum is also actively working with the Electric Marathon.<ref>https://ukraine-kiev-tour.com/electric-marathon-2015-kiev-monte-carlo.html</ref><ref>http://www.lvivtoday.com.ua/upcoming-lviv/4532</ref><ref>http://www.uadn.net/2016/05/04/ukrainian-company-organizes-electric-car-rally-through-20-european-cities-to-monaco/</ref><ref>http://www.visitmonaco.com/en/AllNews/Lviv-Monte-Carlo-Electric-Marathon-%E2%80%93-An-Ecological-Challenge</ref>

omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = <!-- default 300px --> | screenshot_alt = | caption = | url = {{URL|politicalgraveyard.com}} | slogan = | commercial = <!-- "Yes", "No" or leave blank --> | type = Political | registration = | language = English | num_users = | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | programming_language = | owner = [[Lawrence Kestenbaum]] | author = <!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = <!-- or: | editors = --> | launch_date = 1996<!-- {{start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | revenue = | alexa = <!-- {{increase}} {{steady}} {{decrease}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/example.com ##] (US/Global MM/YYYY) --> | ip = | issn = <!-- ISSN, e.g. 1085-6706 (automatically linked to http://www.WorldCat.org) --> | oclc = <!-- OCLC number, useful where an ISSN has not been allocated (automatically linked to http://www.WorldCat.org) --> | current_status = | footnotes = }} '''The Political Graveyard''' is a [[website]] and [[database]] that catalogues information on more than 277,000 [[Politics of the United States|American political figures]] and [[List of United States political families|political families]], along with other information.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-gazette.com/living/2016-06-22/joan-griffisillinois-ancestors-political-graveyard-site-not-what-you-think.html|title=Joan Griffis/Illinois Ancestors: Political Graveyard site not what you think|date=June 22, 2016|first=Joan|last=Griffis|work=[[The News-Gazette (Champaign-Urbana)|The News Gazette]]}}</ref>
==History== The database attempts to capture very basic biographical and office-holding data for its political figures. Besides where they are buried,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zach Hagadone |title=The Political Graveyard |url=https://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/the-political-graveyard/Content?oid=3922709 |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=Boise Weekly |date=2 November 2016 |quote=If you're sick to death of politics, take a stroll through The Political Graveyard (politicalgraveyard.com), which logs where more than 200,000 U.S. politicians are buried.}}</ref> it records dates and locations of birth and death, offices held and the applicable dates, organizational affiliations, and cause of death. It also reports their relation (at least by blood and marriage) with other politicians listed, their [[List of political parties in the United States|political party]], and limited military history. The names are sorted and indexed by surname, birthplace, positions held, demography, religion, occupation, cause of death, and final resting place, with each entry usually having fewer than five lines of text.
The name comes from the website's inclusion of the burial locations of the deceased, when known.
The site was created in 1996 by [[Lawrence Kestenbaum]],<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Mark Leibovich]] |title=Hitting a Self-Destruct Button |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/01/weekinreview/01leib.html |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=New York Times |date=1 October 2006 |quote=“You always seem to have politicians doing bizarrely self-destructive things, especially involving sex,” says Lawrence Kestenbaum, creator of “Political Graveyard,” a history Web site that includes an exhaustive cataloging of transgressions by politicians.}}</ref> then an academic specialist at [[Michigan State University]], and later on staff at the [[University of Michigan]]. Kestenbaum was formerly a county commissioner, and in 2004 was elected to be [[County Clerk]]/[[Register of Deeds]] of [[Washtenaw County, Michigan|Washtenaw County]], [[Michigan]]. The site and its underlying database were developed from a personal interest triggered by the ''Biographical Directory of the U.S. Congress'', which was its original data source. Since then his personal research, and the information contributions of hundreds of volunteers have greatly expanded the information available. It is licensed under the "Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 1.0" [[Creative Commons License]].
Over the years the definition of "eligible political figure" has been expanded. It now includes most high federal officials, [[ambassador]]s, all elected and some appointed [[U.S. state|statewide]] officeholders, and many mayors. It lists unsuccessful candidates, presidential electors, and delegates to [[U.S. presidential nominating convention]]s of the major political parties.
Politicians are listed alphabetically, by office held or sought, and by location of birth, residence, and death. Some are listed in categories, including occupations, ethnicity, religious and organizational affiliation, honors and awards. Politicians accused of crimes or touched by scandal are listed by the nature of the accusation, as well as by decade and by state. Cause of death is broken down into dozens of categories.
The site also lists [[political families]]. Individuals listed on the site are linked together if their relationship meets the [[Rule of 1/1000 common ancestry]]. Each cluster of three or more linked politicians is treated as a family, with family name and location assigned by an [[algorithm]]; the largest individual family cluster is the Kennedys, with 34 members. The site's largest cluster, with 2,134 members, is called "Two Thousand Related Politicians"; most of the larger families are subsets of this group, with each subset defined and named by an algorithm. The largest subset family is the Huntington-Chapin-Waterman family of Connecticut, with 229 members.

[[Democratic and Socialist Union of the Resistance|UDSR]] | colours = | country = France }} The '''Third Force''' ('''''Troisième Force''''') was a French coalition during the [[French Fourth Republic|Fourth Republic]] (1947–1958) which gathered the [[French Section of the Workers' International]] (SFIO) party, the centre-right [[Democratic and Socialist Union of the Resistance]] (UDSR), the [[Radical Party (France)|Radicals]], the Christian democrat [[Popular Republican Movement]] (MRP) and other centrist politicians, opposed both to the [[French Communist Party]] (PCF) and the [[Gaullist]] movement. The Third Force governed France from 1947 to 1951, succeeding the ''[[tripartisme]]'' alliance between the SFIO, the MRP and the PCF. The Third Force was also supported by the conservative [[National Centre of Independents and Peasants]] (CNIP), which succeeded in having its most popular figure, [[Antoine Pinay]], named [[Prime Minister of France|Prime Minister]] in 1952, a year after the dissolving of the Third Force coalition. ==History== During the later decades of the Third Republic, the majority of French voters and deputies belonged to the spectrum of numerous small liberal and republican parties of the centre-left and centre-right. During election-time, this spectrum tended to split in half, its centre-left wing cooperating in electoral lists with the main socialist party ([[French Section of the Workers' International|SFIO]]) and its centre-right wing with the main Catholic party ([[Republican Federation (France)|URD]]). Periodically, however, the parties of the broad centre attempted to form an alliance amongst themselves to lock out socialists and the religious right from power: the policy of creating a government of 'third force' through the tactic of 'republican concentration'. At that time, given the balance of political support and the divisions among the republicans, such a tactic was rarely successful. After the war and the installation of the Fourth Republic, the appearance of powerful mass political movements on the far-left and far-right, the Communists and Gaullists, provided a renewed incentive for the miscellaneous parties of the centre to combine their forces to lock out the extremes. The Third Force government was organised after the dismissal of vice-premier [[Maurice Thorez]] and four others Communist ministers from [[Paul Ramadier]]'s government during the [[May 1947 crisis]]. The May 1947 crisis can be summarized as: "The Communists' refusal to continue support for the French colonial reconquest of Vietnam on one hand and a wage-freeze during a period of hyperinflation on the other were the immediate triggers to the dismissal of Thorez and his colleagues from the ruling coalition in May 1947". Nevertheless, the heterogeity of the Third Force increased the ministerial instability. Although it kept its majority after the [[French legislative election, 1951|1951 legislative election]], in part due to the change of voting system, it split over economic policies, ''[[laïcité]]'' and the financing of denominational schools. The Socialists left the cabinet and the following governments were formed by centre and centre-right parties: the [[Radical Party (France)|Radical Party]], the UDSR, the MRP and the [[National Centre of Independents and Peasants]] (CNIP) The idea of reviving a Third Force between the centre-left and the centre-right in France has been raised periodically ever since. The Socialist [[Gaston Defferre]] and the Radical [[Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber]] advocated such an alliance in the 1960s, culminating in Defferre's disastrous candidacy in the [[French presidential election, 1969]]. Presidents [[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing]] and then [[François Mitterrand]] unsuccessfully tried to revive the Third Force, the latter doing so in a sense by pursuing a policy of "ouverture" toward the UDF after the failure of the Socialists and their allies to gain an outright majority in the [[French legislative election, 1988]]. However, each time, the most important right-wing party, the [[Rally for the Republic]] (RPR), opposed itself to such an alliance.
