{{about|William Ferguson "Fergie" Reid|the Scottish-born Australian legislator|Fergie Reid}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = William Ferguson Reid | image = 2018-05-26 1243 William Ferguson Reid.png | state_delegate = Virginia | district = [[Henrico County]] | preceded = [[T. Coleman Andrews, Jr.]] | succeeded = [[Howard Carwile]] | term_start = January 10, 1968 | term_end = January 8, 1975 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1925|3|18}} | birth_place = [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], [[Virginia]], [[United States|U.S.]] | alma_mater = [[Virginia Union University]]
[[Howard University]] (M.D.) | spouse = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] }} '''William Ferguson "Fergie" Reid''' (born March 18, 1925) is a Virginia physician, politician and [[civil rights activist]]. In 1968, Reid became the first [[African-American]] elected to the [[Virginia Assembly]] since the days of [[Civil War (US)|Reconstruction]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lva.virginia.gov/exhibits/political/william_reid.htm|title=William Ferguson Reid|work=virginia.gov|accessdate=19 September 2015}} He won re-election twice to the [[Virginia House of Delegates]], representing Richmond and part of surrounding [[Henrico County, Virginia|Henrico County]]. The 90 for 90 campaign{{cite web|url=http://wsls.com/2015/07/07/lawmakers-part-of-90-for-90-campaign-to-get-new-registered-voters/|title=Lawmakers part of 90 for 90 campaign to get new registered voters|work=WSLS|accessdate=19 September 2015}} organized by [[Chesterfield County, Virginia]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] in 2015 to encourage broader voter participation, especially in [[gerrymandered]] precincts, was organized in honor of Reid's 90th birthday.{{cite web|title=90 For 90 Initiative: Honoring Dr. William Ferguson Reid,|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mODhSmu4kRU|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=26 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=90 for 90|url=http://www.90for90.org/copy-of-women-1|website=90 for 90|accessdate=5 March 2018|language=en}} ==Early and family life== Fergie Reid was born in Richmond on March 18, 1925, the son of dentist Leon Reid and his wife.Stop #12 on [[Maggie Walker]] Tour{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/mawa/learn/photosmultimedia/upload/Jackson-Ward-Podcast-transcription.pdf |format=PDF |title=Jackson Ward Podcast |publisher=Nps.gov |accessdate=2015-09-20}} He grew up in a house next to that of prominent banker and activist [[Maggie L. Walker]] at 110 Leigh Street in Richmond's [[Jackson Ward]]. Both houses shared the same street number, and one day "a courtly man with a Van Dyke beard" appeared at the Reid family's door, mistaking it for the Walker residence. The stranger proved to be scholar and civil rights activist [[W. E. B. Du Bois]].{{cite web|last1=Times-Dispatch|first1=JEFF E. SCHAPIRO Richmond|title=Schapiro: One Va. history-maker remembers another - 'Miss Maggie'|url=http://www.richmond.com/news/virginia/government-politics/jeff-schapiro/schapiro-one-va-history-maker-remembers-another---miss/article_46910a4a-88cc-5174-8574-c3165353f6ce.html|website=Richmond Times-Dispatch|accessdate=30 July 2017|language=en}} Reid was 9 years old when Maggie L. Walker died in 1934, but long remembered her vividly, "She was widowed and living with her children and grandchildren . . . . Naturally we were together every day in our house or their house; so we were very close." He could name Walker's grandchildren-- "Maggie, Laura, Armistead, Mamie Evelyn and Elizabeth"—and that Elizabeth was his age.{{cite news|last1=Schapio|first1=Jeff E.|title='Miss Maggie' was neighbor of another Va. history-maker|publisher=Richmond Times-Dispatch|date=July 30, 2017|location=Richmond, Virginia|pages=B1, B10}}Stop #12 on [[Maggie Walker]] Tour{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/mawa/learn/photosmultimedia/upload/Jackson-Ward-Podcast-transcription.pdf |format=PDF |title=Jackson Ward Podcast |publisher=Nps.gov |accessdate=2015-09-20}} In 1941 Reid graduated from [[Armstrong High School (Virginia)|Armstrong High School]], and in 1946 he received his bachelor's degree from [[Virginia Union University]]. He earned his medical degree from [[Howard University]], and served his internship and residency as a surgeon in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. After the civil rights events described below, Reid and his wife eventually moved to [[Chevy Chase, Maryland]]. Both their daughters and son (William Ferguson Reid, Jr.) became physicians, with the daughters practicing in Maryland and New Jersey and their son in [[Hollywood, California]]. Reid was active in his [[Episcopal Church (USA)|Episcopal Church]] and the [[Salvation Army]], as well as with [[Omega Psi Phi]] and became a 32nd degree Mason.http://dela.state.va.us/dela/Membios.nsf/94f6e9b9c9b5678f85256b1b00732227/4befa4ea29a5671285256c4c005621c2?OpenDocument ==Career== Dr. Reid served as a lieutenant in the [[United States Navy]] during the [[Korean War]], with the [[1st Marine Division]], and later at the [[Bethesda Naval Hospital]] in Maryland. Returning to Richmond, he became active in civic and professional affairs. He served on the staff of Richmond Memorial Hospital, Richmond Community Hospital, Retreat for the Sick, [[Medical College of Virginia]] and [[St. Mary's Hospital (Richmond)|St. Mary's Hospital]]. His professional associations included the [[American College of Surgeons]], [[Richmond Academy of Medicine]], Richmond Medical Society, [[Medical Society of Virginia]], Old Dominion Medical Society, [[American Medical Association]] and the National Medical Association. He became a diplomate of the American Board of Surgery in 1955.{{cite web |title=Check a certification |url=https://www.absurgery.org/app.jsp?bounce=app_vc_searchvc |publisher=[[American Board of Surgery]]}} ==Civil rights activism== Reid co-founded the Richmond Crusade for Voters in 1956. He hoped to register and mobilize black voters during [[Massive Resistance]].{{cite news|title=Nurturing the Roots: 90for90 and Black Political Power|url=http://progressive.org/dispatches/nurturing-roots-90for90-black-political-power/|accessdate=26 May 2018|work=Progressive.org|date=15 July 2016|language=en-us}} He was a [[de facto]] member of the [[Civil Rights Movement]]. Senator [[Harry F. Byrd Sr.]] and his Democratic political machine in Virginia largely controlled statewide politics. According to Michael Paul Williams of the [[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]: "This was an era of poll taxes, literacy tests and other mechanisms to weaken black political clout. The entrenched Byrd [[political machine]] stood in defiance of change."{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Michael Paul |title=Dr. William Ferguson Reid |url=https://www.richmond.com/special-section/black-history/dr-william-ferguson-reid/article_b26338cb-1e2d-5e59-94f9-be5d66da1787.html |accessdate=4 August 2018 |work=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]] |date=10 February 2003 |language=en}} Reid, John Mitchell Brooks and Dr. William S. Thornton began meeting daily at the old Slaughter's Hotel, a popular segregation-era gathering place for black Richmonders in [[Jackson Ward]]. The outgrowth of these strategy sessions was the Crusade.{{cite web|url=http://www.richmond.com/special-section/black-history/article_b26338cb-1e2d-5e59-94f9-be5d66da1787.html|title=Dr. William Ferguson Reid|work=Richmond Times-Dispatch|accessdate=19 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2015/04/19/1377788/-90-for-90-Getting-out-the-vote-in-Virginia#|title=90 for 90. Getting out the vote in Virginia|work=dailykos.com|accessdate=19 September 2015}} African Americans gained national support with the Civil Rights Movement through the passage of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] and the [[Voting Rights Act]] of 1965. An important outcome was Federal oversight and enforcement of voting rights. Under Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act, decisions affecting elections became subject to clearance by the [[U.S. Department of Justice]]. ==Political career== The Crusade had been formed in 1955 to register more voters to combat the racist politics driven by the era of "[[massive resistance]]," part of a Southern strategy to thwart the [[U.S. Supreme Court]]'s rulings that public schools be desegregated. "No civic organization did more to democratize local politics in 20th-century Richmond than the Crusade," opined [[University of Richmond]] history professor Dr. Julian Maxwell Hayter in his book, "The Dream Is Lost: Voting Rights and the Politics of Race in Richmond, Virginia."{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=Bonnie Newman|title='We Decided to Start a Third Party'|url=http://richmondmagazine.com/news/sunday-story/we-decided-to-start-a-third-party/|website=richmondmagazine.com|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en-us|date=18 February 2018}} Reid co-founded the Richmond Crusade for Voters with Dr. William Thornton, John M. Brooks, Ethel T. Overby and Lola Hamilton. Despite the Crusade for Voters' continuing growth in influence, Reid's first two candidacies for public office failed. In 1965, he was 7th among the eight candidates seeking the five seats in the [[Virginia House of Delegates]] representing Richmond (part-time positions). However, the [[Byrd Organization]] was crumbling. In early 1966, Virginia's [[Harry F. Byrd]] died of a brain tumor, and two of his prominent lieutenants, conservative Democrats, Rep. [[Howard W. Smith]] of [[Virginia's 8th congressional district]] and U. S. Senator [[A. Willis Robertson]], lost in the Democratic primary. In the summer of 1969, the Democratic Party engaged in a bitterly fought gubernatorial primary and "an exhausting run-off election which left the old organization fragmented and set the stage for "the election of [[Linwood Holton]]", a Republican who had lost his first gubernatorial run in 1965.{{cite web|url=http://scholarship.richmond.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1350&context=masters-theses |format=PDF |title=Linwood Holton's long quest for the governorship of Virginia and its impact on the growth of the Republican Party |publisher=Nps.gov |accessdate=2015-09-20}} The first [[African American]] to be elected to the [[Virginia General Assembly]] since 1891, Reid took his seat in the lower chamber the following January, alongside [[Eleanor P. Sheppard]], who had opposed school closings and became Richmond's first female mayor. Others winning the nine seats in the [[Virginia House of Delegates|House of Delegates]] from Richmond City and [[Henrico County, Virginia|Henrico County-Richmond]] were veterans [[George E. Allen, Jr.]], [[Junie L. Bradshaw]], [[Thomas P. Bryan]], [[Ernst W. Farley, Jr.]], [[Edward E. Lane]], [[E. B. Pendleton, Jr.]].Cynthia Miller Leonard, Virginia's General Assembly 1619-1978 (Richmond: Virginia State Library 1978) p. 749 Reid replaced prominent segregationist [[T. Coleman Andrews, Jr.]], a prominent segregationist who would found the [[American Independent Party]] in 1969 to support the presidential candidacy of George C. Wallace of Alabama.New York TImes obituary 4/20/1989 However, in 1968, Virginians voted in record numbers for the second successive time in a presidential election since adoption of the [[24th Amendment]] removed the [[Poll tax (United States)|poll tax]] as a bar to participation in Federal elections. name="richmond.edu" Reid would serve three terms in the [[Virginia General Assembly]], winning re-election in 1969 (when [[Carl E. Bain]] and [[B. Earl Dunn]] replaced Thomas P. Bryan and E.B. Pendleton).Leonard p. 755 In 1971, after the 1970 census led to legislative reapportionment, [[Robert B. Ball Sr.]], [[Edwin H. Ragsdale]] and [[T. Dix Sutton]] were elected from Henrico County, Reid from the district of Henrico and Richmond City, and Allen, Bain, Lane, Sheppard and newcomer Philip B. Morris represented Richmond City.Leonard pp. 760, 762http://dela.state.va.us/dela/Membios.nsf/HSearch/?SearchView&Query=%5BFullName%5D+Contains+william%20ferguson%20reid+&SearchMax=&SearchOrder=4 Although Reid was the only African American in the General Assembly when he took office in 1968, in 2000 there were fifteen.{{cite web|last1=Political|first1=Exhibitions:|title=William Ferguson Reid|url=http://www.lva.virginia.gov/exhibits/political/william_reid.htm|website=Library of Virginia|publisher=Virginia|accessdate=2 October 2015}} In 1973, Reid was defeated by colorful Richmond city councilman [[Howard Carwile]], also African-American, who vowed to "raise hell", but was defeated for re-election in 1975 by prominent lawyer [[Gerald L. Baliles]].Virginius Dabney, Richmond: the Story of a City (University of Virginia Press 1992) pp. 337-338Leonard pp. 767, 774 After his final term as delegate ended, Dr. Reid then accepted a position as regional medical officer with the [[U.S. State Department]], which caused him to maintain a home in Washington, D.C.'s Maryland suburbs, as well as travel abroad. His activism then continued from a distance, as the Crusade for Voters helped win an African American majority on Richmond's City Council and elected [[Henry L. Marsh]] the city's first African American mayor in 1977. Reid has also recorded an oral history for [[Virginia Commonwealth University]], available online.{{cite web|url=http://dig.library.vcu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/voices/id/8 |title=Interview with Dr. W. Ferguson Reid :: Voices of Freedom |publisher=Dig.library.vcu.edu |date=2003-03-21 |accessdate=2017-10-22}} The Henrico County School Board in 2012 named a school in honor of Dr. William Ferguson Reid.{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Michael Paul |title=Williams: Name new Henrico school after Dr. William Ferguson Reid |url=http://www.richmond.com/news/williams-name-new-henrico-school-after-dr-william-ferguson-reid/article_45fa0fb0-164b-559d-b380-7f776c2b6915.html |work=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]] |date=9 October 2012 |language=en}} ==90 for 90 campaign== In honor of Reid's 90th birthday, in 2015 in [[Chesterfield County, Virginia]], the 90 for 90 voter registration goal based on door-to-door volunteer canvassing began. The 90 for 90 voter outreach program spread throughout the [[Commonwealth of Virginia]] and beyond.{{cite web|last=Dahl |first=Wills |url=http://baltimorepostexaminer.com/ferguson-reids-movement-can-bring-change-virginia/2015/02/22 |title=Ferguson Reid's movement can bring change to Virginia - Baltimore Post-ExaminerBaltimore Post-Examiner |publisher=Baltimorepostexaminer.com |date=2015-02-22 |accessdate=2015-09-20}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2015/04/04/1375598/-DKos-Asheville-Dr-Fergie-Reid-and-Jr-coming-to-Roanoke# |title=DKos Asheville: Dr. Fergie Reid and Jr coming to Roanoke |publisher=Dailykos.com |date=2015-04-04 |accessdate=2015-09-20}} In 2015, Denise Oliver Valdez wrote for ''[[Daily Kos]]'' that "While much of the media is focusing on presidential hopefuls for 2016, the state of Virginia has key elections coming up this year—elections for the Virginia House of Delegates.... A unique effort is underway in Virginia to get voters registered and out to vote, not just this year, but in the election years to come. The impetus and inspiration behind this drive is a civil rights icon in Virginia, Dr. William Ferguson Reid, known to many as 'Fergie,' who was the first black man to win a seat in the Virginia General Assembly since Reconstruction." == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [[Richmond Times-Dispatch]] [http://www.richmond.com/special-section/black-history/article_b26338cb-1e2d-5e59-94f9-be5d66da1787.html] Republished from 2003 profiles BY MICHAEL PAUL WILLIAMS Times-Dispatch Staff Writer. * Source: State Board of Elections, Statement of the Vote General Election, Tuesday, November 7, 1967. ~--'5State Board of Elections, Statement .2f the Vote Cast,1968, 1964, 1960. * [[Richmond Times-Dispatch]], by guest columnist Nancy Finch.''RECRUITING CANDIDATES—Finch: Would you like to run for office?[http://www.richmond.com/opinion/their-opinion/guest-columnists/article_d5647be8-0c98-59d0-9804-32c30c7edcae.html] {{DEFAULTSORT:Reid, William Ferguson}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Politicians from Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:Physicians from Virginia]] [[Category:Virginia Democrats]] [[Category:Members of the Virginia House of Delegates]] [[Category:Civil rights activists]] [[Category:Virginia Union University alumni]] [[Category:Howard University alumni]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Political activists]]
